title: Quiz 1: Critical Care Concepts & Facilities
description: Foundational concepts of critical care nursing, types of patients, and facility requirements including Acute Rooms and ICUs.

questions.question: What term is defined as 'the turning point of a disease for better or worse, especially a sudden change'?
questions.explanation: According to Dorland's Pocket Medical Dictionary, a crisis is defined as the turning point of a disease for better or worse.
questions.hint: The word 'Critical' is derived from this term.

questions.question: Which of the following is the recommended nurse-to-patient ratio for an Acute Room?
questions.explanation: It is recommended that a nurse should always be in the acute room, preferably at a ratio of one nurse to two patients at any given time.
questions.hint: It is less intensive than ICU (1:1) but more than a general ward.

questions.question: Which of the following are essential equipment for an Acute Room? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Acute rooms require suction, oxygen, IV apparatus, and observation equipment. MRI and Dialysis machines are specialized equipment not standard for a basic acute room setup.
questions.hint: Think about basic life support and monitoring needs.

questions.question: Match the specialized Critical Care Unit to its specific patient type:
questions.explanation: CCU is for heart conditions, NICU for newborns, Renal units for dialysis, and HDU serves as a step-down unit.
questions.hint: Match the organ or age group to the unit name.

questions.question: The minimum number of beds required to establish a cost-effective Intensive Care Unit (ICU) is ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The minimum number of beds to establish an ICU should be four to merit the staffing and equipping of the unit.
questions.hint: Any number smaller than this is not considered cost-effective.

questions.question: A Burns Unit requires the same standard of equipment and staffing as a general Intensive Care Unit.
questions.explanation: In an ideal situation, a burns unit is supposed to meet all the requirements of an intensive care unit, plus strict infection control.
questions.hint: Think about the severity of major burn injuries.

questions.question: Analyze the table below regarding Facility Requirements. Which requirement is INCORRECT for an ICU?

richContent.content:
FeatureRequirement
Nurse:Patient Ratio1:1
Laboratory24-hour service
Bed Allocation1 bed per 200 hospital beds
SpaceDouble general ward space

questions.explanation: The ideal bed allocation is 1 bed for every 50 beds in the hospital, not 1 per 200.
questions.hint: Look closely at the proportion of ICU beds to hospital beds.

questions.question: Arrange the priorities of intervention for a critically ill patient according to the ABC principles:
questions.explanation: The ABC principles dictate: Airway first, then Breathing, then Circulation.
questions.hint: It follows the alphabetical order A-B-C.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the 'Acute Room' concept?

options.text: A specialized theatre for emergency surgery
A cubicle in a general ward for patients needing close observation
A waiting area for ICU admission
An isolation room for infectious diseases

questions.explanation: An acute room is set up in a ward (cubicle/corner) for patients needing critical care in hospitals without established ICUs.
questions.hint: It is often found in smaller hospitals lacking full ICUs.

questions.question: Which criteria are used to classify a patient as 'Critically Ill'? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Severe injuries to head or chest
Presence of a chronic manageable disease

questions.explanation: Critical illness involves immediate threat to life, severe structural damage, or failure of vital systems (circulation/breathing). Chronic manageable diseases are generally not 'critical' in this context.
